file_name: Bagade 等 - 2024 - Efficient data transmission over 5G Networks with improved accuracy using 802.11p.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 利用802.11p在5G网络上实现高效数据传输并提高准确性
structured_info.title_en: Efficient data transmission over 5G Networks with improved accuracy using 802.11p
structured_info.abstract: High-quality data traffic management providing ultra-low latency and less circuit complexity are the technical challenges for 5G cellular networks in recent years. To address the increased data rate traffic and enhance the user experience, buffer management with effective utilization of resources are 5G networks. The existing research contains uncompressed or raw video data transmission over a double buffer system. The spectrum is always busy with information if uncompressed data is sent. Transmission delays occur while packet transmission and receiver systems result in video buffering. The authors proposed an optimized resource framework in this research paper by compressing data using a modified H.265 Lagrangian Encoder and transmitting data using a single buffer technique. The transmission delays are mitigated, and data buffering is minimized with reduced transmission errors. The proposed method is tested and verified with various errors like collision error, propagation error, sensing error, and accuracy. The proposed model gives an improvement in accuracy when compared with the existing model.
structured_info.methodology: Modified H.265 Lagrangian Encoder for video compression, single buffer technique with Markov chain modeling, IEEE 802.11p protocol for vehicular communication, and MATLAB simulations for error analysis.
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed framework reduces transmission delays by 4.87% compared to existing models through optimized compression and single-buffer management, significantly minimizing propagation, sensing, busy receiver, and collision errors in 5G video streaming.

analysis.Overview: Proposes an optimized 5G video transmission framework using H.265 compression and single-buffer management to reduce latency and errors, validated through IEEE 802.11p simulations.
Background_and_Motivation: Rising video traffic strains 5G networks, causing buffering and quality degradation.
Existing double-buffer systems transmit uncompressed video, leading to spectrum congestion and delays.
Authors highlight inefficiencies in current queuing models and buffer policies affecting Quality of Experience (QoE).
Links specific buffer management challenges to broader 5G network optimization needs for ultra-low latency applications.
Telecommunications, network optimization, and multimedia systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Modified H.265 Lagrangian Encoder: Video compression method reducing data size; Single-buffer technique: Queue management minimizing delays; IEEE 802.11p: Protocol for vehicular communication with collision avoidance.
Compression enables efficient transmission → Single-buffer handles packets via Markov chain → 802.11p manages physical/MAC-layer communication.
Packet arrivals follow Poisson distribution; buffer states are ergodic; uniform power distribution in 5G base stations.
Provides a novel integration of video compression, queuing theory, and vehicular protocols to enhance 5G performance.
Methodology: Markov chain models finite single-buffer system; H.265 compression at 30fps/2K resolution; IEEE 802.11p simulations for error analysis.
Novelty: Combines compression with single-buffer optimization. Applicable to vehicular networks. Rationale: Compression reduces spectrum load; single-buffer simplifies queuing.
Simulated traffic densities (40–180 vehicles/km), distances (0–500m), transmission powers (10–30dBm). Data preprocessed for highway scenarios. Representativeness limited to simulated conditions.
Rigorous MATLAB testing of four error types (propagation, sensing, busy receiver, collision). Metrics: Received Packet Ratio (RPR) and accuracy validated against baselines.
Follows queuing theory (Little’s Theorem) and IEEE communication standards, focusing on discrete-event analysis for network optimization.
Results: 4.87% accuracy improvement over existing models; propagation/sensing errors reduced by 5%; RPR increases with higher transmission power (30dBm optimal).
Results show consistent error reduction across traffic densities. Reliability confirmed via repeated simulations with 0.5% deviation; stability demonstrated under variable distances/powers.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Problem (existing buffer inefficiencies) → Solution (compression + single-buffer) → Validation (error simulations) → Results (accuracy improvement).
1. Critique raw video/double-buffer limitations; 2. Propose H.265/single-buffer framework; 3. Model buffer via Markov chain; 4. Simulate IEEE 802.11p errors; 5. Compare accuracy/RPR gains.
Strengths: Comprehensive error taxonomy. Weakness: Limited discussion of real-world interference. Rebuttals: Address hidden-terminal issues via collision avoidance in 802.11p.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Integrates video compression with network optimization; introduces Markov-based buffer model; achieves 4.87% accuracy gain.
Simulation-based; lacks real-world channel variation testing; assumes ideal Poisson arrivals.
Queuing theory focus overlooks machine learning alternatives; conclusions constrained to predefined traffic scenarios.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positioned as a direct improvement over prior queuing models (e.g., M/M/1) and H.264-based transmission.
Technical terminology (QoE, RPR, PHY layer); persuasive tone emphasizing efficiency gains; contrasts 'proposed' vs. 'existing' models.
Cites foundational work (Little’s Theorem) to establish credibility; references recent IEEE standards to justify 802.11p adoption.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Single-buffer H.265 compression reduces 5G transmission errors by 4.87%, enhancing video streaming accuracy.
Extend to real-world 5G deployments; explore deep learning for dynamic buffer tuning; test in dense urban environments.
